I am one of those people who are nervous about creating an effect just
for testing.  To test methods that only modify private fields like you
describe, you can use reflection (which I would personally prefer).  Use
the object's getClass() method then Class's getField() method.  Field
extends java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject which has a
setAccessible(boolean) method you can use to gain access to a private
field through reflection.  Field has getter methods for its value.
 
A security manager can be set up to prevent this bypassing of the
private restriction, but by default you are allowed to do it.
 
Matt

	Pico Geyer wrote:
	
	> For example how do you test a:
	> 1) Method that only modifies private fields and has no
corresponding
	> getter method to see if the field is now at the correct value
	
	If there is no directly-visible effect of a method, then you
must either:
	
	(1) Use an indirectly visible effect to see whether the method
did its 
	job. (Ex: change on disk, in a database, e-mail sent)
	
	(2) Create a directly-visible effect "just for testing".
	
	Some people are nervous about option #2, but I'm not. Testing is

	important enough. If you're concerned about hiding these extra
methods 
	from client, then hide them behind an interface.
